fields.description: AutoScaling Policies and CloudWatch Alarms have a many-to-many relationship, meaning a scaling policy can have multiple alarms (see http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/autoscaling/describe-policies.html) and an alarm can be attached to multiple policies.  We need to better handle the display of scaling policies with multiple alarms in a given policy -- perhaps change the scaling policies page from a tile view to a table view?  Screenshot attached.
fields.summary: Scaling Policies page for an ASG needs to better handle multi-alarm policies

comments.body:
[~ethomas], [~gholms]: Could you confirm if a scaling policy can have multiple alarms?  It seems the relationship between scaling policies and CloudWatch alarms is many to many, as a scaling policy may have multiple alarms (looking at http://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/autoscaling/describe-policies.html), and an alarm may be attached to multiple scaling policies.  

Assuming a policy may have multiple alarms, if a scaling policy has the following conditions, will it scale based on either alarm threshold being crossed (i.e. is it an OR condition)?  For example, if I have a scaling policy that scales up by 1 instance, and the policy has a CPUUtilization alarm > 80 percent *and* a RequestCount alarm > 1000 (for the ASG's ELB), will the scaling group scale up if either alarm threshold is crossed?
[~ethomas], [~sjones]: Any ideas on my question in the earlier comment w.r.t. the relationship between scaling policies and alarms?  Perhaps we can discuss this at the next architecture meeting?

[~kgill], I believe you are correct that an alarm can reference multiple scaling policies and that multiple alarms can reference any given scaling policy. Alarms are independently evaluated so for each alarm the scaling policy will be evaluated when that alarm fires (i.e. OR)

[~jloza]: See Steve's comments noted in this ticket.  Perhaps for 4.3 we could convert the scaling policies to a table? And perhaps we could allow alarms to be added to or removed from policies when we work on GUI-2540?

[~kgill]

To my knowledge, an alarm can execute up to 5 "alarm actions" per state, and the alarm actions we currently support are scaling policies, so an alarm can be associated with multiple scaling policies.  Which order they get executed I think depends on the order they are associated, though I haven't tried much with this.
Wireframe updated, thanks [~kgill]!

[~jloza]: I discovered an issue with scaling policies and alarms -- it seems we're mistakenly adding the scaling group name to the dimensions when an alarm with an EC2 metric that doesn't have the scaling group as the dimension is selected during scaling policy creation.  

For example, if I create a scale up policy and select an alarm with dimensions 'InstanceId = i-123456', the dimensions will eventually be set to 'InstanceId = i-123456, AutoScalingGroupName = some-scaling-group'.  Since we're not displaying the existing alarm's dimensions on the alarm details page (perhaps we should?), there's no way to tell the alarm's dimensions are broken, and I discovered this when displaying the alarms for a given policy while working on GUI-2543.

UPDATE: I fixed the dimensions issue in GUI-2559 (PR https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1912).  The relevant commit is at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/commit/26ec0c4cfdb10068e
hi [~kgill], we do display the alarm's dimensions on the alarm detail page, not sure what you mean. Can you clarify, please?

[~jloza]: I suggest that, in addition to the dimension select field, we display the dimensions as static text (perhaps near the top?).  The dimensions chosen field only handles alarms with a single dimension (not counting the ELB/zone case), making it difficult to determine when an alarm is "invalid" when it has multiple dimensions.

Displaying the dimensions as a static field would offer two benefits.  First, it would shed light on alarms with invalid dimensions.  Although the console doesn't support creating alarms with multiple dimensions, euca2ools does, and displaying the dimensions as a static field would make it easier to troubleshoot those "broken" alarms.  Second, when a user is selecting new dimensions from the chosen drop-down on the alarm details page, perhaps it would be helpful to display the original dimensions on the page.

[~jloza]: Looking at the updated wireframe for scaling policies, should we add an alarm name column to the policies table, with each alarm linking to the alarm details page?  If we only display the alarm threshold and dimensions, it's a bit difficult to determine what alarms are set for each scaling policy.

hi [~kgill], 

1) Yes, let's add the alarm name to the scaling policies table (to the left of the dimensions please in case I don't get time to update that wireframe soon. 
2) Do you mean euca2ools allows creation of invalid alarms? If so, that seems like a bug, rather than something we should support in the console. LMK.

[~jloza]: euca2ools supports creating alarms with multiple dimensions... it needs to in order to handle the ELB/zone case (e.g. LoadBalancerName=elb-one, AvailabilityZone=zone-one).  Our console, as it stands now, doesn't handle non-ELB/zone cases where alarms are created with multiple dimensions, and displaying the alarm dimensions as static text would shed some light on those "invalid" alarms IMO.  Or perhaps we could display a notice/warning when an alarm with a non-ELB metric is created with multiple dimensions, since that really isn't a valid alarm?
PR is at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1915

hi [~kgill], yeah, if we read one that isn't valid, we could just display a lightbox that we've detected some invalid stuff and then not display the dimensions on the dialog itself, or put warning text next to the dimension selector. Thoughts?

[~jloza]: Either approach (dialog or inline warning) works for me.  The warning text next to the dimensions selector is probably simpler to implement, but the dialog is more catchy for sure and might be preferred since the alarm is pretty much busted in the non-ELB non-custom-metric multi-dimension case, right?
Hi [~kgill], Yeah, I tend to agree. Could you please opena ticket for that and we can get that in and work out the dialog text TBD?
[~jloza]: I've filed GUI-2565 to track adding the invalid dimensions warning.
[~kgill], feel free to have this code reviewed and merged, just leave the ticket in review and assigned ot me and I'll do the UX review when I can. My calendar is a bit insane today and tomorrow.

[~dkavanagh]: Could you code review https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1915 and merge if it looks good?  Per Jenny's earlier comment please assign it to her for UX review after merging the PR.

Small nits:

* alarm name should be to the left of threshold column as indicated in previous comment
* Add button text does not match wireframe
* Table header should not display if there are no scaling policies defined, it should just show the add button please
* alarm threshold column is too wide
* dimension column is too narrow (dimension should be able to display without wrapping in case we need to stack more than 1
* threshold value does not match wireframe

- alarm name should be to the left of threshold column as indicated in previous comment [UPDATED, note that the prior comment indicated the alarm name should be left of the *dimension* column]
- Add button text does not match wireframe [FIXED]
- Table header should not display if there are no scaling policies defined, it should just show the add button please [FIXED]
- alarm threshold column is too wide [FIXED by matching threshold to wireframe]
- dimension column is too narrow (dimension should be able to display without wrapping in case we need to stack more than 1 [FIXED]
- threshold value does not match wireframe [FIXED, although the wireframe is missing the statistic (e.g. *Average* CPUUtilization)]  Let me know if you want to add the statistic.]

thanks [~kgill], almost there! One tiny thing:

The actions icon is not centered in the column under the header.

[~jloza]: The actions icon alignment issue affects all landing pages (on Chrome).  GUI-2574 has been filed to track that issue, as it doesn't seem to be a quick fix and isn't isolated to the scaling group policies page.
[~jloza]: Just a heads up that https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1915 has been merged, so use the master branch if you want to review this again.
UX review passed, ready for code review

I think this ticket is good to be approved, although the row seems to escape the white bounding box of the scaling policies pane (on the right side):
 !sgpolicies.png|thumbnail! 

Is this an issue? Should I open up another bug on that?
[~jloza], per Steve's comment above, and I saw this in FF and IE11 as well. should we fix this for 4.3?
Kicking back to [~kgill] for a quick fix today to get this into 4.3. Thanks!
Fixed in https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/2027
Good to merge once test pass. If I don't merge today, feel free to on Friday.
